question: Which technique makes clustering unchangeable, and what issues arise in handling various clusters versus one identifying dense regions?
contexts:
['3/24/2021 69Introduction to Data Mining, 2nd Edition   
Tan, Steinbach, Karpatne, KumarHierarchical Clustering:  Problems and Limitations
Once a decision is made to combine two clusters, 
it cannot be undone
No global objective function is directly minimized
Different schemes have problems with one or more of the following:
–Sensitivity to noise 
–Difficulty handling clusters of different sizes and non-
globular shapes
–Breaking large clusters
3/24/2021 70Introduction to Data Mining, 2nd Edition   
Tan, Steinbach, Karpatne, KumarDensity Based Clustering
Clusters are regions of high density that are 
separated from one another by regions on low density.
69
70']
ground_truth: Hierarchical Clustering is the technique that makes clustering unchangeable once a decision to combine two clusters has been made. The issues arising from different clustering techniques, such as Density Based Clustering, include sensitivity to noise, difficulty in handling clusters of varying sizes and non-globular shapes, and breaking large clusters.
